xxl.core.cursors.joins
Class SortMergeEquivalenceJoin<I,E>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<E>
      xxl.core.cursors.joins.SortMergeJoin<I,E>
          xxl.core.cursors.joins.SortMergeEquivalenceJoin<I,E>
Type Parameters:
I - the type of the elements consumed by this iteration.
E - the type of the elements returned by this join operation.
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterator<E>, Cursor<E>
public class SortMergeEquivalenceJoin<I,E>
extends SortMergeJoin<I,E>

A sort-merge implementation of the equivalence-join operator (especially the equi-join). This class provides a generic, untyped sort-merge join algorithm. The join predicate has to be a equivalence-relation and the elements of both input iterations have to be sortable according to an order which provides the members of the equivalence-classes in sequence. In contrast to the upper class SortMergeJoin, the sort-merge equivalence-join provides support for left-outer, right-outer and full outer joins. The resulting tuples of any join operation are generated by a user defined function realizing a kind of factory method. The binary function newResult can be used to map the result tuples to an arbitrary user defined type. The sweep-line status structure, here called sweep-area, consists of a bag with an additional method for reorganisation. The way the elements of the input iterations are inserted into the according sweep-area is determined by a given comparator. Depending on the result of the comparison of the two next input elements of the input iterations, the left (sortedInput0) or right (sortedInput1) input is processed. If the left input is processed, the sweep-area's of sortedInput0 and sortedInput1 are reorganized and the next element of sortedInput0 is inserted in sweepArea0. After that sweepArea1 is queried with this element, i.e., the specified predicate is applied on the elements contained in sweepArea1 and the last inserted element of sweepArea0. In order to perform an effective search in the sweep-area, the query method of the bags should be overriden. If the binary predicate returns true the evaluated tuple gets an result of the join operation. After that query the mapping function to create the result-tuples is applied on the results detected by the predicate and after that they are returned to the user. The right input is processed analogous. The implementation is a bit more complex due to additional checks of join-types and the generation of result-tuples where the evaluated join predicate returned false.

Note: When the given input iteration only implements the interface Iterator it is wrapped to a cursor by a call to the static method wrap.

Example usage (1): 

   SortMergeEquivalenceJoin<Integer, Object[]> join = new SortMergeEquivalenceJoin<Integer, Object[]>(
       Arrays.asList(0, 1, 3, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9).iterator(),
       Arrays.asList(0, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10).iterator(),
       new SortMergeEquiJoinSA<Integer>(
           new ListSAImplementor<Integer>(),
           0,
           2
       ),
       new SortMergeEquiJoinSA<Integer>(
           new ListSAImplementor<Integer>(),
           1,
           2
       ),
       ComparableComparator.INTEGER_COMPARATOR,
       Tuplify.DEFAULT_INSTANCE,
       Type.OUTER_JOIN
   );
   
   join.open();
   
   while (join.hasNext())
       System.out.println(java.util.Arrays.toString(join.next()));
   
   join.close();
The input iterations of this simple example are two list iterators. The first one is based on all odd numbers and numbers that can be divided by 4 of the interval [0, 10]. The second input iterator contains all even numbers of the same interval. The join predicate, an equalality predicate, is encapsulated in the given sweep-areas based on a list. In order to compare an element of sortedInput0 and an element of sortedInput1, a default comparator for integers is used. In this example no specific function is specified to create user defined result-tuples. The identity function delivers the result-tuples in their original representation, namely as an array containing the matching elements of the input iterations. This can simply be seen when printing the result-tuples to the output stream. But in the package xxl.core.relational there are different factory methods creating a particular kind of tuple, e.g., array-tuple, list-tuple, that substitute the tuplify function. So, let us consider the output of this join operation, which looks as follows: 
   [0, 0]
   [1, null]
   [null, 2]
   [3, null]
   [4, 4]
   [5, null]
   [null, 6]
   [7, null]
   [8, 8]
   [9, null]
   [null, 10]

See Also:
Iterator, Cursor, NestedLoopsJoin, SortMergeJoin

Constructor Detail

SortMergeEquivalenceJoin

public SortMergeEquivalenceJoin(Iterator<? extends I> sortedInput0,
                                Iterator<? extends I> sortedInput1,
                                SortMergeEquiJoinSA<I> sweepArea0,
                                SortMergeEquiJoinSA<I> sweepArea1,
                                Comparator<? super I> comparator,
                                Function<? super I,? extends E> newResult,
                                SortMergeJoin.Type type)
                         throws IllegalArgumentException
Creates a new sort-merge equivalence-join operator backed on two sorted input iterations using the given sweep-areas to store the input iterations' elements and probe for join results. Furthermore a function named newResult can be specified that is invoked on each qualifying tuple before it is returned to the caller concerning a call to the next method. This function is a kind of factory method to model the resulting object.

Precondition: The input cursors have to be sorted and the join predicate has to be an equivalence-relation!

The result-tuples created by this operator are represented as an array of the input iterations' elements that are participated in this join result. If the user wants to specify a different result-type, a mapping function newResult can be specified. This function works like a kind of factory method modelling the resulting object (tuple). Further a set of comparators have to be specified, in order to compare the elements of different input iterations. Every iterator given to this constructor is wrapped to a cursor.

Parameters:
sortedInput0 - the first sorted input iteration to be joined.
sortedInput1 - the second sorted input iteration to be joined.
sweepArea0 - the sweep-area used for storing elements of the first sorted input iteration (sortedInput0).
sweepArea1 - the sweep-area used for storing elements of the second sorted input iteration (sortedInput1).
comparator - the comparator that is used for comparing elements of the two sorted input iterations.
newResult - a factory method (function) that takes two parameters as argument and is invoked on each tuple where the predicate's evaluation result is true, i.e., on each qualifying tuple before it is returned to the caller concerning a call to the next method.
type - the type of this join; use one of the enumeration's element defined in superclass.
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the specified type is not valid.

SortMergeEquivalenceJoin

public SortMergeEquivalenceJoin(Iterator<? extends I> input0,
                                Iterator<? extends I> input1,
                                Function<? super Iterator<? extends I>,? extends Iterator<? extends I>> newSorter0,
                                Function<? super Iterator<? extends I>,? extends Iterator<? extends I>> newSorter1,
                                SortMergeEquiJoinSA<I> sweepArea0,
                                SortMergeEquiJoinSA<I> sweepArea1,
                                Comparator<? super I> comparator,
                                Function<? super I,? extends E> newResult,
                                SortMergeJoin.Type type)
                         throws IllegalArgumentException
Creates a new sort-merge equivalence-join operator backed on two input iterations using the given sweep-areas to store the input iterations' elements and probe for join results. The constructor does not require the two input iterations to be sorted. The two specified, unary functions newSorter0 and newSorter1 will be invoked on the corresponding input iteration in order to get a sorted input. Furthermore a function named newResult can be specified that is invoked on each qualifying tuple before it is returned to the caller concerning a call to the next method. This function is a kind of factory method to model the resulting object.

Precondition: The join predicate has to be an equivalence-relation!

The result-tuples created by this operator are represented as an array of the input iterations' elements that are participated in this join result. If the user wants to specify a different result-type, a mapping function newResult can be specified. This function works like a kind of factory method modelling the resulting object (tuple). Further a set of comparators have to be specified, in order to compare the elements of different input iterations. Every iterator given to this constructor is wrapped to a cursor.

Parameters:
input0 - the first input iteration to be joined.
input1 - the second input iteration to be joined.
newSorter0 - an unary function that sorts the first input iteration input0.
newSorter1 - an unary function that sorts the second input iteration input1.
sweepArea0 - the sweep-area used for storing elements of the first input iteration (input0).
sweepArea1 - the sweep-area used for storing elements of the second input iteration (input1).
comparator - the comparator that is used for comparing elements of the two input iterations.
newResult - a factory method (function) that takes two parameters as argument and is invoked on each tuple where the predicate's evaluation result is true, i.e., on each qualifying tuple before it is returned to the caller concerning a call to the next method.
type - the type of this join; use one of the enumeration's element defined in superclass.
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the specified type is not valid.

SortMergeEquivalenceJoin

public SortMergeEquivalenceJoin(Iterator<? extends I> sortedInput0,
                                Iterator<? extends I> sortedInput1,
                                Function<?,? extends SweepArea<I>> newSweepArea,
                                Comparator<? super I> comparator,

                                SortMergeJoin.Type type)
                         throws IllegalArgumentException
Creates a new sort-merge equivalence-join operator backed on two sorted input iterations using a parameterless function to create the required sweep-areas that are used to store the input iterations' elements and probe for join results. Furthermore a function named newResult can be specified that is invoked on each qualifying tuple before it is returned to the caller concerning a call to the next method. This function is a kind of factory method to model the resulting object.

Precondition: The input cursors have to be sorted and the join predicate has to be an equivalence-relation!

The result-tuples created by this operator are represented as an array of the input iterations' elements that are participated in this join result. If the user wants to specify a different result-type, a mapping function newResult can be specified. This function works like a kind of factory method modelling the resulting object (tuple). Further a set of comparators have to be specified, in order to compare the elements of different input iterations. Every iterator given to this constructor is wrapped to a cursor.

Parameters:
sortedInput0 - the first sorted input iteration to be joined.
sortedInput1 - the second sorted input iteration to be joined.
newSweepArea - a parameterless function creating a new sweep-area that is used for storing elements of the sorted input iterations.
comparator - the comparator that is used for comparing elements of the two sorted input iterations.
newResult - a factory method (function) that takes two parameters as argument and is invoked on each tuple where the predicate's evaluation result is true, i.e., on each qualifying tuple before it is returned to the caller concerning a call to the next method.
type - the type of this join; use one of the enumeration's element defined in superclass.
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the specified type is not valid.
